conbody.p:
A box provides the basis for content positioning. Using boxes, you can specify the layout of almost any combination of widgets. The following types of boxes are available:
Horizontal
Vertical

A horizontal box lays out its contents horizontally. From a technical point of view, imagine that the box is divided into a table containing one column per child widget. Each column, by default, has the same width and each child widget is placed in a separate column. Sometimes, a widget requires more space than the horizontal box would normally allocate to it. In this case, the box automatically allocates this extra space to display all its contents even if it means that the browser must show horizontal scroll-bars.

A box usually takes up all the available width of its parent container, but only takes up the minimum amount of height required to display all its contents. This behaviour can be modified (see section
for more information). In design mode, a grey border is displayed around the box. This box is not displayed in the running application. This border makes it easier for you to visualize the structure of the module and to select the correct box while designing the module.
